review_title: Inpatient Pharmacy: Understaffed, unrealistic expectations, and very unprofessional atmosphere.
job_title: Pharmacy Technician I in Pueblo, CO
pros: Pay would be one of the few pros of this job. Also, bonuses are not too common, but generous when available. Only ten hour shifts are available, so three days off per week is cool.
cons: If you like catty co-workers and supervisors who gossip to each to each other, then about each other, manager sleeping with pharmacists, and bossy, think they own the pharmacy Tech II and III's then this might be your calling. When you're new, the older techs group against you, and talk about you every chance they get. If we need help, you're scrutinized for needing it. Very unprofessional language is an everyday thing, and the managers don't mind joining in also. Aside from always being short staffed, never steady schedules, and never getting breaks, this place is miserable.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in Pueblo, CO

review_title: Great co workers, terrible pay and management
pros: Some Co workers are great and helpful
cons: The new grads this year will be making more than nurses who have been there 2 years. Management came around telling all the RNs they're getting a $1 raise because they looked at surrounding hospitals and found that they were underpaying us. They're underpaying by $3, and only gave us a $1 raise. On top of that they asked us to not tell the CNA's because they're severely underpaid as well. Due to them paying absolute garbage wages, we're ALWAYS understaffed. Instead of paying their FT employees why they deserve they prefer to pay for half of their work staff to be travel nurses. Also these travel nurses get away with ALOT. One travel nurse called someone a racial slur and instead of her being fired immediately, they let her stay and put her on opposite shifts. Another employee, who was a minority, was made to sit with a known racist pt. Nobody had communicated that he was racist to the employee made to sit with him and she ended up being choked by this pt. Also the hospital recently went through a rebranding. During nurses week a brand representative handed out candies to the employees. During this time, the CEO stood there with her backs to all her employees and didn't say a word to them.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Small so it is easy to become close and familiar with staff
cons: Small so there may be a lack of staff resources for continued job specific education options. Short staffed

pros: Parkview pays PRN employees very well.
cons: However, full-time and part time pay is very low throughout all departments. Low morale and short staffed.

pros: Very hands on job. Great for those needing experience and education. Lots of opportunities.
cons: Poorly paid, overworked and very understaffed, stressful environment. When raising concerns with management, no changes are made. Employees are taken for granted and are basically told to put up. You will enjoy the first 6 months of employment then come to realize how undervalued you are!

review_title: Extremely poor pay for years of experience

Managers doesn't have a clue on how to do the work themselves so you can never ask for help.  Managers always lead you down a stray path towards failure and not victory.  Limited Career Advancement.

review_title: Do not pay well for experience.

job_title: Front Office Assistant in Pueblo, CO
pros: Working with patients and having great Doctors who were knowledgeable and took very good care of their patients. Having the right tools needed to perform the job efficiently and effectively. Having good resources to utilize when needed.
cons: Too much gossip among coworkers with little to no repercussions. Too much focus on hear say and not enough focus on encouraging high quality, efficient team and individual work from management. Not a professional work environment.

review_title: Okay to work at when you are new to health field
pros: Gratifying to work there when you see patients
cons: Disrespect from multiple different departments

review_title: Wonderful group of people to work with
pros: Honestly?  I had a home floor, but when I went to other floors I always worked with wonderful staff from the nurses all the way down to phlebotomy, respiratory therapy, maintenance, kitchen staff, and environmental services.  Everyone here takes pride in what they do and works hard.  Management does acknowledge it especially when the hospital is short staffed and delivers snacks once in a blue moon when this happens.
cons: They need to pay their staff more if they want to keep them.  CNA base pay is $$10.20 and nurses are about $22, but they supposedly pay you "based on experience" however many of the experienced people I had in orientation were making the base pay.  They spend more on traveler nurses (who are wonderful) but most people leave either for better pay, incentives, or a better schedule in the case of RT since they're basically always on call.  If you work nights then be prepared to always be understaffed because night shift differential doesn't really make up for it and some floors will screw with your schedule and have you work every other day.  Some people can function that way, but if you work nights then it ends up being difficult and you lose a lot of sleep.  Because they're determined to keep staff, on certain floors they forgive being late and poor patient care unless you tell someone higher than the director.

pros: Most people that work here are wonderful to interact with.
cons: Pay needs to be better, some directors are very difficult to work with and may not let you transfer out of the department.

pros: Team unity and support. Call Bonus every quarter.
cons: Mandatory call. Working 23 hours straight with no relief. Physicians question your nursing judgment.

pros:
Autonomy 
Both clinical and staff experience
Friendly staff
cons:
Varied shifts including nights, weekends and holidays 
Lower pay compared to other hospitals

pros: My coworkers are awesome and everyone helps everyone
cons: Benefits and pay aren’t great, their nurses aren’t a priority to them

pros: Pro's would include great management.
cons: I live roughly 45min away.

review_title: Only Option for Southern CO Nurses
pros:
Coworkers
Local for southern CO
Hires/ Trains New Grads
cons:
Low pay
Some units have abysmal management
Pt ratios high

pros: I value many of my fellow employees, I have AMAZING patients, and I love my job!
cons: As an internal applicant who is highly qualified with experience and higher education, my numerous attempts to transfer out of my current department have failed miserably. I was told recently by my charge nurse (who I have never told that I have applied for other positions) that as long as my current Director is in her position, I will never have the opportunity to transfer out of the department, and that she has essentially "trashed" me when other directors have inquired about me as a prospective transfer. I have attempted to address this through HR and was trashed by my director there.  Where is the justice in any of this?  In my department I have no "career path".  I have been offered absolutely no opportunities for advancement as far as certifications are concerned. I am degraded in front of other nurses and physicians on a regular basis.  This has also been addressed with HR to no avail. I, along with my fellow employees believe there should be some other way for Directors to obtain references regarding prospective employees.  Although I enjoy the department I am currently in, I do not feel "safe" in staying there as far as my license is concerned.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Pueblo, CO
pros:
Parkview holds an annual family day for their employees at the Pueblo City Zoo. I went several years in a row with my family and had a great time.
I believe Mike Baxter is a great CEO, with good intentions.
Parkview’s upper management culture seems consistently happy and upbeat.
cons:
Physicians are rude to the RN's, and other support staff. When brought to management's attention, about a physicians behavior, inappropriate screaming and belittling of staff…they just looked the other way. I have even seen RNs hesitate to call a physician because fear of getting yelled at.
Work/life balance does not exist at Parkview if hold a clinical position. Every department varies on (on-call requirements and minimum mandatory hours per week ) based on staffing needs. Not all departments experience equal workloads. Moral and since of making a difference for the greater good is crushed; when night after night you have some departments killing themselves while other are stuffing their face and playing on their phone.
As in every work environment you have some negative people. With that said, I have seen some really great employees get bullied out, or be pushed to the edge because of a work load or the harshness of other employees.
Parkview is the only place I have worked where the employees actually give up, because the workload and the demand is too much to take.

pros: Great coworkers. Stressful at times but that’s any job.
cons: Lots of turn over. Filled in quite a bit and not enough people to cover shifts

job_title: Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) in Pueblo, CO
pros:
Great teamwork
Interesting work environment
Understanding Management
cons: Sometimes there is a lack of hours for PRN/part time

job_title: One Call Scheduling in Pueblo, CO
pros: Health Insurance is fairly good
cons: There is Bad Management and Favoritism. No opportunity for growth.

review_title: I have been with Parkview Medical Center for 18 years and do hope to retire from Parkview.
pros:
-Recently had a catastophic family emergency and I can't thank Parkview enough for support from HR, Employee Health, Director of the program  and many other leaders and staff for support while gone.  
-I have had to opportunity to advance some in the 18 years i have been here and have seen a lot of good changes.  
-I worked for both Centura and for Parkview and my preference is Parkview, however my family had always been a Centura fans.  
-Have had the opportunity to discuss pay and pleasenatly surprised at the results in the change.
-Great physicians but challengig schedules
-I do believe Parkview wants to hear what people think
-Benefits are among the best around
cons:
-Advancement previously held Administrative Assistant for two VP at Parkview and at Centura when changes made resulting in reorganiztion I was lucky enough to stay with Parkview however, when reapplying  later for VP assistant the requirement required an Associates Degree which did not even qualify me for an interview although I had the experience.  
-Salaries can use some adjustment
-Someimtes changes made to department without knowing the full impact on staff

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Good pay for mist employees
cons: Not loyal To long term

pros:
This is a smaller hospital, so it has a family type feeling, so you won't feel like your lost and just another number, other staff and management will know who you are.
Management is pretty approachable about issues and concerns, which is not common at most healthcare facilities.
cons:
Pay is horrible at this place, the hospital can be a lot more competitive if they want to. This is very disappointing, that they take care of their upper management financially and but no where near being competitive with the working class. Most people are aware of management getting yearly bonuses each year, give at least some of that to the working class.
Turn-Over is High with nursing staff.

pros: The pay is above average for the region. They tend to grow leaders from within which is great from an opportunity standpoint. They have the best general surgery group around. They have a profit sharing program.  Most likely going to be acquired by a larger corporation which will improve opportunities.
cons: The physical plant is awful, been added on to so many times it's like a maze. Very difficult for patients and families to navigate the labyrinth. Parking is problematic for both employees and families. They want employees to park off site in a not so lovely section of town and take a shuttle to the hospital. There is never any budget for education. The biggest problem with this hospital is they are experiencing tremendous growth in some areas, but access to resources tends to be difficult in the evenings and on weekends. They want to be a big trauma center, but you can't even get an x ray read after 4 pm.

pros: Parkview has been a big part of my life and truly a "member of my family" for 30 years.  I love working because of the family atmosphere. I feel like coworkers and management care about the quality of services we provide to our patients and there is a feeling of belonging to a great team of people that stick together and help each other accomplish that goal.
cons: As in any big organization there is a very small percentage of employees that abuse the system and their colleagues end up doing extra work to cover for them thus creating unnecessary morale problems.  Holding everyone accountable is one of our values, but sometimes it seems like the "cheaters" (long breaks, smoking breaks, fake sick days, etc. )don't get held accountable.

review_title: Decent place to work, but looking for something better.
pros: As others have said, the staff generally cares about the best patient outcomes. Team work amongst staff is good but there are still those few desk flies that don't help. There is some profit sharing and 401k isn't bad.
cons: 12 hour shifts with no regard to employee satisfaction when scheduling. Below average pay. They schedule you 6 weeks out which is great but you always end up working every weekend as there is a requirement to work so many weekends every 6 weeks. The attendance policy is criminal. You call off sick and you're not allowed to use sick time right away, you must use 8 hours of PTO first. Patient loads for aides are high and as I said before there are RNs who feel above potty trips and won't help out. Management is concerned about issues that don't pertain to current situations.

review_title: Have been working less than a year. Orientation is the best one I have ever attended. Great team work on the floor.
pros: Orientation is top notch. Good team work on the floor where I work. Friendly atmosphere and good CNA help. Sincere concern for patient outcome.
cons: Biggest problem is the computer system is not well designed and put together. Patient touch and Meditech do not talk to each other and this causes a lot of duplicate work and time spent on computer that could be given to patient care. Also there is still too much paper work and charting for a system that is suppose to be fully computerized. Lots of lessons to be learned from Cerner and Epic.   Also need to hold MD's more accountable to using the computer system. Pay grade could be a little more competitive, and equipment upgraded, especially the IV pump system.

pros: Parkview is a community of staff dedicated to your personal and professional growth.  If you are interested you can seek out opportunities to work on new projects and develop new skills.  HR has excellent resources that can help you complete college education and continuing education.  There is a terrific university in town that can help you meet your educational needs.  Parkview's culture is very supportive to students and administration is highly supportive of educational endeavors.  Another big pro is that Parkview is not part of a system.  As such the supervisory teams engage employees on the front lines in decision making processes so that we can serve our local community's needs.  The decisions that are made are aligned with patients that are seen here at our facility.  There is no corporate administration in a far-away town making decisions for operations - our leaders live in our community and take the time to understand our challenges and our successes.
cons: I love working at Parkview and I can't imagine working anywhere else!

job_title: Inpatient Pharmacy Technician in Pueblo, CO
pros: You are compensated well for you time
cons: The department level management is a joke. The chair of the pharmacy hides in his office all day and avoids any interaction with the pharmacists or technicians. Technician supervisor puts in place procedures that she would never do her self and represents techs for not doing them either . supervisor makes unrealistic goals and plans. Meetings are held almost every month that they make "mandatory" and are a giant waste of time. Management will make promises to fix moral and never follow through with them. This is the worst work environment that I have ever worked in. Everyone is miserable and complains about everything all the time. The hours are horrible. One shift you have to wake up at 3 to be there and another one you're there until 1200 am. The department is not flexible with kids school schedules and has a high turn over. If anyone calls off they are always shorthanded and never have anyone to cover.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Pueblo, CO
pros: Personally I absolutely love my job at Parkview Medical Center.  I have worked here for over 3 years and it is by far the best job I have ever held.  The company has great benefits including a 401 K plan, generous amounts of PTO, great health and dental insurance, they even helped me to pay off my school loans.
cons: Occasionally it can be difficult to get my schedule switched around to have a certain day off, but 90% of the time this is not the case, and when it does happen it is usually because I want a day off with short notice.

pros: The people who work at this medical center are amazing.  Maryalicia Verdecchia of HR helped with my interview and new employee process and she could not have been more accomodating, professional and kind.  Although I was offered higher paying jobs, I was so impressed by the warm, professional attitude of Parkview that I accepted a position here.  They go out of their way to be helpful.  This medical center is a successful leader in state of the art technology and medical care, and yet they have not lost their values or caring, professional way in which they deal with people.
cons: I can think of none yet.

review_title: Not horrible--ok place to get exp if you can't find work up north or don't like bigger cities.
pros: Easy to get a job here (lots of turnover in med/surg nursing especially), solid teamwork and staff who in general really care about patient outcomes, some really talented surgeons and internists and specialist doctors, decent 401k matching if you want to stay 6 years or more, occasional profit sharing, smaller town atmosphere in Pueblo that's pretty safe with minimal traffic and somewhat lower cost of living.
cons: Weak pay and benefits, hard to use sick time (must take first 8 hours as PTO which encourages folks to take off several days), no on-call schedule for nursing so if someone does call off sick you're simply screwed for that shift, middle management with little or no experience/education in management, high turnover means new grads are frequently oriented by people with a year or less experience, "orientation" is confusing and little more than unstructured role-modeling for 4-6 weeks, little attention paid to clinical best practices unless related to medicare/medicaid reimbursement, poor communication structure throughout the hospital plus poor staffing choices leading to confusion and stress for all involved which leads inevitably to weaker patient care.

pros: Knowledgeable leads and co workers. Good Internal Communication.  Positive Work Environment. Great leads and Director. A nice balance of technical and soft skills opportunities in each work day.
cons: Pay is at market level.  This is fair. However, it takes a minute to realize Pueblo has a lower cost of living so the initial sticker shock is bigger than what you actual need to be concerned with.  It is easy to make a living on the salaries here.

review_title: Positive and professional working environment, patient focused and team collaboration is incredible!
job_title: Student Nurse Extern in Pueblo, CO
pros: The staff and administration take the time to complement your contribution as a healthcare tem member. Whenever I needed guidance, I never felt intimidated to ask for help.
cons: Shortage of staffing and patient ratio was difficult to handle at times. However, the integrity of the nursing staff held the unit together for the best interest of the patient. (This came at a personal sacrifice to many though)

pros: Parkview Medical Center is a great place to work.  There are a lot of long term employees here, including our Senior Management Team.  Working here feels like one big family.  We're all here to meet the same Mission and Vision and to provide excellent service and quality care to our community and our patients.  There are always opportunities for career growth as well as educational opportunities.
cons: I can't think of any cons.  It's just a great place to work.

job_title: Fellowship Program Coordinator in Pueblo, CO
pros: CEO takes time to learn everyone's name. Working for Parkview is like working for a large family.There are so many employee related events for wellness and employee appreciation. It is a place to gain experience and make friends along the way.
cons: The health coverage isn't the best. Raises are done across the board and not performance based. In some departments there is not much room for growth.

review_title: The real life of the Parkview ER Tech
pros:
Scope expands through the roof.  Here as an ER Tech you will do iv, lab draw, 12 lead ekg, EJ, IO, wound anesthesia, wound care, custom splinting and many other small things not compared to the above core responsibilities. 

You will become one of the IV experts of the hospital and be able to hang with flight for life for your IV skills. If you want to become insanely good with these skills this is the place for you.

It is rare for us to do an IO  ( drilling into the bone for access ) you will become so creative where you can get an IV on a pt you learn to make it happen. You will have more level 1 and 2 trauma then you can ever keep count of you will become very good at sticking kiddos as well. Once again thousands of IV sticks a year
cons: We are more busy then ever in the ER.  Depending on how the schedule lands the ER Tech can be responsible for 12 to 27 patients by yourself while your 70 + pts deep in the waiting room. While this is happening pueblo has a very bad heroin problem so most of your pts veins will be shot this can consume time even for the best of us. Besides that group of pts you also have some other groups that for medical reasons have veins in bad shape that can be a great challenge. On top of that you will get calls from the floors for help because that floor of nurses, the doctor, and other floors that sent their best sticks need help because they all failed to establish an IV thus everyone counts on you all while this is happening. You can drawn very easily here but if you make it you will be one ofnthe best in this aspect of ems.

pros: I enjoy the work I do and the projects that have been thrown my way to increase my knowledge and experience.
cons: Culture of the office is very dysfunctional. The pay is below average for not only the accounting office but around the organization as a whole.

review_title: Room for Improvement but excellent staff
pros:
CEO Mike Baxter is engaging, remembers employee's names (very impressive with around 3000 employees) and genuinely seems to care.

Many employees are excellent, especially among RNs.

Physicians and mid-levels are excellent.

Hospital is clean.

High level of care is consistently provided to patients.
cons: Need for improved technical issues and improved support for nursing staff from other departments. This is honestly my biggest complaint. A task as simple as checking a blood sugar can take an inordinate amount of time when patient touch devices lose service or crash for no apparent reason. Glucometer scanners are hypersensitive and inadvertent scanning of blood band or other barcodes results in threats of mandatory education or locking nurses out of using glucometers entirely. Pt. touch devices are programmed to ask nurses for illogical follow-ups (yes, I really did give that 30 mL of prostat, why am I charting this twice?) Pharmacy techs are routinely rude when answering the phone and medications can take HOURS to arrive despite multiple calls and requests, despite being ordered stat. It is simply accepted among nursing staff that when ordering many things in meditech, for example an enteral feeding pump or formula, one must also call sterile stores or distribution or the item wont arrive for hours. Physical Therapy, Occupational Therapy, and Speech therapy generally do an excellent job but at times are impossible to find (patients need these services on weekends just as much as weekdays). These are just examples of a generalized problem of stacking tasks on nurses. Unfortunately, this takes time away from patient care. Also, the idea of retaining staff would be better served by across the board raises for: critical care, period. The acquisition of advanced certifications. Having a bachelors degree These are clear cut rewards and would be better at retaining gifted staff instead of a highly complicated and somewhat arbitrary tier system. Need for a more comprehensive list of protocols, although to be fair this is improving.

pros: Great benefits package, motivated leadership works hard and are constantly inspired to improve the facility, friendly coworkers, excellent work environment, strong footing for future in community.
cons: Sometimes too lenient to folks that mess up. If it is a sentinal event you cause, no question, pack your bags. But some folks aren't engaged and you can tell. They just believe in people so much that they give them opportunity after opportunity to try to improve. For some, that works out. For others, they take advantage.

review_title: Management doesn't look out for the staff or the patients only the doctors and their needs so they don't leave.
job_title: Certified Surgical Technician in Pueblo, CO
pros: Most of the Doctors are very nice to work with.  Peer staff can be like family if you stay out of the drama.
cons: Management never does what they say they are going to do.  The patient does not come first which is MAJOR in my eyes.  Some staff can be very cliquish.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Pueblo, CO
pros: Decent pay..float pool staff are amazing!
cons: Management NEVER gives compliments, always points out negative. Staff and management are highly vindictive and everyone talks about everyone behind their back.. if you’re not in the right “clique” they will do everything possible to make you leave. Management seems to delight in turning staff against each other. No team work in sight on the middle floor of the main hospital..

job_title: Patient Financial Services Representative in Pueblo, CO
pros: The management is great. The coworkers are awesome.  The pay and benefits are good.  I may not want to get up in the morning but going to work makes it worth the effort.
cons: It has gotten so big that you don't get to know people as well as when it was smaller unless you get involved in teams.

pros: Good people work here who really care about their patients. The job is interesting and they pay fairly competitively. Small community feel at this hospital.
cons: They go through a lot of training for how to be a good company representative but they should really focus on listening to the staff's concerns about pay and keeping enough staff to cover all of the shifts.

pros: Friendly staff, easy to get employment
cons: No holiday pay, no weekend pay, always short staffed, extremely low pay for Colorado.

pros: Health care will always provide some sort of employment.
cons: Salary is low compared to other facilities that provide the same employment within the same town. Management (Director's,Lead Clinical Educators,etc.) are a "clique".

pros:
Great CEO, very involved and engaged. Overall a very positive direction and bringing salaries up to be more competitive. Some very impressive leadership. 
Reason for leaving - relocation.
cons: Difficult to keep up with growth (not enough staff), outdated/inadequate EHR, although that was planned to be replaced. Some longtime staff resistant to the positive direction - "change".

pros: Profit share. That was always something special to look forward to twice a year,
cons: Co-workers with an attitude. A small handful that jump from one department to another doing very little work but complaining about other workers until those reported give up and quit.

review_title: Not much room for growth, quickly becoming overwhelmed with SMC closing.
pros: Great co-workers. If you’re close friends with management your job should be secure...
cons: Upper/senior management is horrible. New CEO is driving the company straight into the ground and Parkview will most likely sell out to UC Health in the next couple years. Management will tell you to your face for years how you’re stellar and the best crew, only to have them sell you out at the first opportunity.
